Description: Twenty-four finches, varying in pose and color, are perched in a row. This watercolor is a variant of one of the artist's most popular subjects, "Un bâton de cage." Another variation of this composition in the Lucas Collection of The Baltimore Museum of Art is inscribed: "Giacomelli a Mr. Lucas affecteux souvenir d'une aquarelle." Henri Beraldi wrote of this artist, "Giacomelli is the Van Huysum [Jan Van Huysum, 1682-1749, Dutch flower-painter] of tiny birds, tender and ravishing, which give the impression of being pensive. The bird is to Giacomelli what the cat is to Lambert [Louis-Eugène Lambert, 1825-1900, French painter who specialized in cat subjects]. A respectable bird must be a Giacomelli bird; A non-Giacomelli bird is a false bird," (H. Beraldi, "Les Graveurs du XIXE siècle," Paris, 1885-92, 7:105).

Exhibitions.Textblock: French Master Drawings. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1997-1998.

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: A Discerning Eye: Nineteenth-century Drawings and Watercolors
Exhibitions.Textblock: A Discerning Eye: Nineteenth-century Drawings and Watercolors. Academy Art Museum, Easton. 1998-1999.

Exhibitions.Textblock: The Essence of Line: French Drawings from Ingres to Degas. The Walters Art Museum, Baltimore; Baltimore Museum of Art, Baltimore; Birmingham Museum of Art, Birmingham; Tacoma Art Museum, Tacoma. 2005-2006.

Exhibitions.Textblock: Botanical Delights: Floral Motifs in 19th-Century Art. Government House, Annapolis; Strathmore Hall Art Center, North Bethesda; Academy Art Museum, Easton. 1998-1999.

Exhibitions.Textblock: A Supple Brush: The Flowering of Continental Watercolors. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1979.

Exhibitions.Textblock: A Connoisseur's Portfolio: Nineteenth-century Drawings and Watercolors in the Walters Art Gallery. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1983.

Inscriptions: "H. Giacomelli" in graphite reinforced with watercolor in lower left edge, partially cropped
Medium: watercolor over graphite underdrawing heightened with white and gum on cream, thick, heavily textured wove paper
Provenance: William T. Walters, Baltimore, March 21, 1884, by purchase [from the artist, George A. Lucas as agent]; Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1894, by inheritance; Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: A Perch of Birds
